item.title: Zalman add a quote by Albert Einstein
item.description: "Reality is merely an illusion, albeit a very persistent one." -- Albert Einstein

item.title: Zalman add a quote by Albert Einstein
item.description: "The most incomprehensible thing about the world is that it is at all comprehensible." -- Albert Einstein

item.title: Zalman add a quote by Albert Einstein
item.description: "If we knew what it was we were doing, it would not be called research, would it?" -- Albert Einstein

item.title: Zalman add a quote by Albert Einstein
item.description: "Everything must be made as simple as possible. But not simpler." -- Albert Einstein

item.title: Zalman add a quote by Rodger Kamenetz
item.description: "We can’t choose our poetic fathers any more than our biological ones — but we can choose how to come to terms with them." -- Rodger Kamenetz

item.title: Zalman add a quote by Peter Matthiessen
item.description: "It is related that Sakyamuni [the historical Buddha] once dismissed as of small consequence a feat of levitation on the part of a disciple, and cried out in pity for a yogin by the river who had spent twenty years of his human existence learning to walk on water, when the ferryman might have taken him across for a small coin." -- Peter Matthiessen

item.title: Zalman add a quote by Samuel Beckett
item.description: "I always thought old age would be a writer’s best chance. Whenever I read the late work of Goethe or W. B. Yeats I had the impertinence to identify with it. Now, my memory’s gone, all the old fluency’s disappeared. I don’t write a single sentence without saying to myself, ‘It’s a lie!’ So I know I was right. It’s the best chance I’ve ever had." -- Samuel Beckett

item.title: Zalman add a quote by John Updike, “The Centaur” (1963)
item.description: "What does he mean," I asked, "the humanistic values implicit in the physical sciences?" "You ask him," my father said. "Maybe he knows. Maybe down deep in the atom there's a little man sitting in a rocking chair reading the evening paper." -- John Updike, “The Centaur” (1963)
